text: I wasn't aware of this, what is the reason for not showing the virtual prices by default? I've been using the basic market recorder example from the flumine docs, is there any way to set virtualise=true to request the virtual prices for the recorder? Do I put this in streaming_market_data_filter?

elements.text: I wasn't aware of this, what is the reason for not showing the virtual prices by default? I've been using the basic market recorder example from the flumine docs, is there any way to set virtualise=true to request the virtual prices for the recorder? Do I put this in streaming_market_data_filter?

text: Please would you expand on this Liam? I get the idea of virtualising prices having read the docs, but why wouldn't you want this data?

text: That's true, I could virtualise it myself if needed. Why do you consider it better to have the raw stream Mo?

text:
1. Better to use the raw stream live because of the latency of the virtual stream
2. Can always go raw -> virtual, I would imagine it's impossible to go the other way

elements.text: Better to use the raw stream live because of the latency of the virtual stream
Can always go raw -> virtual, I would imagine it's impossible to go the other way

text: I refuse to use virtualized prices because of the delay.

elements.text: I refuse to use virtualized prices because of the delay.

text: Like Mo said its delayed and basically phantom which you can calculate yourself if required but if you record virtual than virtual is all you are getting and there is no going back to get the real prices

text: Starting to question everything I know/thought I know now. So does this mean that the virtual prices are calculated whenever new real prices change, or that the process itself is delayed and the delay refers only to the stream pushing the virtual prices?

elements.text: Starting to question everything I know/thought I know now. So does this mean that the virtual prices are calculated whenever new real prices change, or that the process itself is delayed and the delay refers only to the stream pushing the virtual prices?

text: <@U4H19D1D2> I have investigated and it looks like your market recorder uses cumulative traded volume. Whereas the historical (pro) data from Betfair does not use cumulative values.

elements.text: I have investigated and it looks like your market recorder uses cumulative traded volume. Whereas the historical (pro) data from Betfair does not use cumulative values.

text: its not me, its betfair, but yes there is a difference between the crap they sell and what you get from the stream

elements.text: its not me, its betfair, but yes there is a difference between the crap they sell and what you get from the stream

text: ah ok, thanks. I wasn't blaming you just wanting to clarify. I can work with either, just needed to know what I was looking at. Thank you.

text:
Not sure tbh but this is the description in the streaming docs, I assume some sort of concatenation takes place rather than 150 m/s delay on each update, send an email to Neil
```Please note: The virtual price stream is updated ~150 m/s after non-virtual prices. Virtual prices are calculated for all ladder levels.```

elements.text: Not sure tbh but this is the description in the streaming docs, I assume some sort of concatenation takes place rather than 150 m/s delay on each update, send an email to Neil
Please note: The virtual price stream is updated ~150 m/s after non-virtual prices. Virtual prices are calculated for all ladder levels.

text: Question with respect to Pinnacle. Wondering what is the maximum bet amount and if there is a difference between a market opening and right before the event. Does anyone have thoughts on that?

elements.text: Question with respect to Pinnacle. Wondering what is the maximum bet amount and if there is a difference between a market opening and right before the event. Does anyone have thoughts on that?

text: Bet amount depends on time to event, and the exact nature of the event

elements.text: Bet amount depends on time to event, and the exact nature of the event

text: Limits are lowest when the market opens, and increase towards start

elements.text: Limits are lowest when the market opens, and increase towards start

text: When you place bet you are locked for a few seconds/minutes until they can refresh their odds (if they want to) after your action

elements.text: When you place bet you are locked for a few seconds/minutes until they can refresh their odds (if they want to) after your action

text: So you can bet a lot on a single event that has low limits, if you're patient

elements.text: So you can bet a lot on a single event that has low limits, if you're patient

text: I'm not sure that you could call it an API as such, but I have seen where someone has managed to harvest their websockets connection for monitoring prices and placing bets.  It still amazes me that the bookies don't actually produce an API to encourage people to bet given that they have the capacity to limit your winnings anyway.

elements.text: I'm not sure that you could call it an API as such, but I have seen where someone has managed to harvest their websockets connection for monitoring prices and placing bets.  It still amazes me that the bookies don't actually produce an API to encourage people to bet given that they have the capacity to limit your winnings anyway.
